article_text:
The U.S. Department of Agriculture on Wednesday predicted that fruit and vegetable prices will rise by 5% to 6% this year due largely to lower production in California's Central Valley. While California has just suffered one of its driest years on records, extreme environmental policies deserve much of the blame for the forecasted spike.

California produces more than half of the country's fruits and vegetables, including the bulk of its lettuce, berries and tomatoes. Federal water regulators this year slashed farmers'...

article_summary:
Federal water regulators this year slashed farmers'...
The U.S. Department of Agriculture on Wednesday predicted that fruit and vegetable prices will rise by 5% to 6% this year due largely to lower production in California's Central Valley.
California produces more than half of the country's fruits and vegetables, including the bulk of its lettuce, berries and tomatoes.
While California has just suffered one of its driest years on records, extreme environmental policies deserve much of the blame for the forecasted spike.
